title: El I-Space ‚ÄòFramework‚Äô
text:
Un pilar fundamental sobre el que se sostiene mi cosmovisi√≥n es el esquema conceptual I-Space (Boisot 1998). Es muy complejo y los invito a explorarlo de primera mano porque el autor aborda la complejidad socio-econ√≥micos en t√©rminos informacionales como nadie. Su an√°lisis de la econom√≠a del conocimiento y su explicaci√≥n del cambio tecnol√≥gico son excelentes. Lamentablemente es un autor pr√°cticamente desconocido en la literatura econ√≥mica.
Yo s√≥lo voy a introducir algunos de sus elementos b√°sicos. Su marco te√≥rico se llama I-Space o Information Space, justamente porque permite representar flujos y activos de informaci√≥n en un espacio de tres dimensiones. Estas tres dimensiones son los grados de codificaci√≥n, abstracci√≥n y difusi√≥n. Al ser evaluadas en grados, al interior de cada dimensi√≥n la informaci√≥n se representa en t√©rminos relativos.

title: Datos, Informaci√≥n y Conocimiento
text: Datos, informaci√≥n y conocimiento son tres conceptos diferentes que muchas veces se utilizan indistintamente. Pero si indagamos en sus interdependencias podemos establecer definiciones m√°s claras. Partamos de la idea de conocimiento.

title: Datos, Informaci√≥n y Conocimiento
text:
¬øQu√© es el conocimiento?

Conceptualizar el conocimiento es, sin lugar a dudas, una tarea compleja. No voy a entrar en definiciones de diccionario u or√≠genes hist√≥ricos, pero cualquiera puede comprobar que el an√°lisis del conocimiento viene de larga data. Para mi, es particularmente √∫til concebir el conocimiento en una relaci√≥n jer√°rquica con los datos y la informaci√≥n (Alavi and Leidner 2001).
La relaci√≥n jer√°rquica es la siguiente: el conocimiento es la capacidad que tiene un agente de procesar datos como informaci√≥n valiosa (Alavi and Leidner 2001; Boisot 1998; Boisot and Canals 2004) . La siguiente figura representa esta relaci√≥n de dos maneras an√°logas y complementarias. El esquema A muestra al agente y al ambiente como entidades separadas, lo que permite incluir el accionar del agente sobre el ambiente. Por otra parte, el esquema B ilustra mejor al agente inmerso y siendo parte del ambiente, aunque no permite observar impacto en el mismo. Prosigamos a analizar cada componente.




Representaci√≥n de un agente y su ambiente en t√©rminos de datos, informaci√≥n y conocimiento. Adaptado de Boisot (1998) y Boisot y Canals (2004).



Los datos son el todo. Tanto el agente como el ambiente, son, y est√°n sujetos a, datos. Boisot y Canals (2004) los definen como estados discernibles de la realidad. Desde el punto de vista de un agente individual, quien tiene la capacidad de organizar datos de manera informativa, los datos representan el input. Es decir, todo aquello que acontece o existe para el agente.
La informaci√≥n es lo que se obtiene a partir de organizar datos y asociarlos de cierta forma para que tengan ‚Äúsentido‚Äù o cumplan un prop√≥sito. M√°s all√° de su impacto en la interpretaci√≥n singular de un agente, la informaci√≥n adquiere particular relevancia en su transmisi√≥n. Por eso, cuando hablamos de informaci√≥n suele involucrase la comunicaci√≥n1. Sin adentraremos en esos temas, podemos considerar la informaci√≥n como un forma de organizar datos que, habiendo un agente capaz de interpretarla, permite transmitir e decodificar un mensaje.
Esta relaci√≥n entre datos e informaci√≥n nos posibilita finalmente a definir el conocimiento como la capacidad que tiene un agente de interpretar, poseer, transformar, utilizar, o compartir informaci√≥n. En su forma m√°s abstracta, un agente es b√°sicamente cualquier sistema que produzca informaci√≥n y adapte sus expectativas/comportamiento en base a ello. En definiciones m√°s restrictivas podr√≠amos contemplar como agentes √∫nicamente como sistemas ‚Äúvivos‚Äù, plantas, animales, humanos, o ‚Äúsociales‚Äù, gregarios.
Lo interesante del conocimiento, al ser una capacidad, es su evoluci√≥n en el tiempo. En el proceso de aprendizaje, ya sea por repetici√≥n o por novedad, un agente modifica su capacidad o actualiza su conocimiento. Compartir y co-producir conocimiento en la interacci√≥n con otros implica adem√°s la necesidad de codificarlo y explicarlo para que se entienda. De esta forma el conocimiento tambi√©n puede tomar forma de activo o ‚Äúasset‚Äù (Boisot 1998) y, al igual que la informaci√≥n, exceder los l√≠mites de agentes individuales.

Aqu√≠ el disruptivo trabajo de Shannon (Shannon and Weaver 1949) y su posterior evoluci√≥n en una teor√≠a de la informaci√≥n amerita una peque√±a disgreci√≥n por su relevancia cultural. Los desarrollos tecnol√≥gicos a partir del trabajo de Shannon, como la creaci√≥n del transistor, revolucionaron como nunca la producci√≥n de conocimiento.

title: Mis principios cosmol√≥gicos
text:
En los √∫ltimos a√±os, gracias a tener que enfrentarme con el desgastante proceso de escribir una tesis doctoral, he podido darle bastante forma a mi manera de pensar e interpretar los fen√≥menos.
Despu√©s de tanto explorar ideas relativas a la producci√≥n del conocimiento, me siento en la necesidad de establecer de manera expl√≠cita algunos rasgos de mi siempre cambiante base cosmol√≥gica. Van entonces cinco aspectos bien generales que te acercaran un poco a mi manera de pensar:

Interpreto los procesos f√≠sicos no solo en t√©rminos materiales sino tambi√©n informacionales. Concibo la infinidad del universo como flujos constantes de datos e informaci√≥n. La teor√≠a de informaci√≥n de Shannon, la mec√°nica est√°distica, y la idea de entrop√≠a me parecen facinantes.
Abrazo la complejidad y la emergencia. Considero que los procesos que acontecen son necesariamente inciertos, aunque tambi√©n influenciables.
A consecuencia de lo influenciable, adhiero al pragmatismo en su deseo y continua b√∫squeda de transformaci√≥n.
Creo que la educaci√≥n y la colaboraci√≥n son el mejor camino para desarrollar capacidades de transformaci√≥n en entornos sociales.
Las capacidades de transformaci√≥n son un elemento transcendental para la producci√≥n social de conocimiento. Mediante el aprendizaje es posible replicar, distribuir, transformar y utilizar informaci√≥n de manera eficiente.

Estos 5 principios, que combinan diversos aspectos cosmol√≥gicos, ontol√≥gicos y epistemol√≥gicos, hacen que mi interpretaci√≥n del mundo sea de cierta manera. La idea de ‚Äúconocimiento‚Äù ocupa un lugar central, ya que funciona como eje conceptual que atraviesa e inter-conecta mis principios. Dos aspectos relacionados mi interpretaci√≥n del conocimiento quiero traer a colaci√≥n: adem√°s de la relaci√≥n entre datos, informaci√≥n, y conocimiento, la representaci√≥n del conocimiento como activo y flujo en un espacio de tres dimensiones.

title: Ian Hulskamp
text:
Hi there!

I‚Äôm Ian ‚Äî a researcher at heart, now turning into a project manager (and soon to finish my PhD in the Information and Knowledge Society at the UOC).As I try to bring theory into practice, I find myself becoming a science manager.
Over the years, I‚Äôve explored how social interactions shape the way knowledge is produced and shared. What drives me is finding ways to put those ideas into practice ‚Äî mainly through collaboration ‚Äî and learning as I go.
If any of this resonates with you, write me. I‚Äôm genuinely interested in what others think.

title: About
text:
If you‚Äôre looking for a more concise overview of my academic and professional path, you‚Äôll find it here: CV.
Right now I‚Äôm working as a Project Manager at the CTTC, a research center in telecommunications technology. Personally? I don‚Äôt know much about telecoms ‚Äî but I‚Äôm genuinely passionate about how knowledge gets produced.
Trained as an economist, I was taught to think in terms of production and optimization. But over time, I‚Äôve come to see knowledge as something that evolves. My drive to understand how innovation, science, collaboration, and learning contribute to this process has led me to specialize in these fields.
I aim not only to keep analyzing these dynamics ‚Äî theory matters to me ‚Äî but also to put ideas into motion. Any social actor has room to grow in how it generates and shares knowledge. Here you‚Äôll find a short story about my own evolution.














Before getting involved in managing over a hundred projects ‚Äî tracking progress, keeping budgets in check, handling communication, and justifying expenses ‚Äî I dove into a PhD in the Information and Knowledge Society at UOC. My thesis (defense coming soon) looks at how different types of collaboration between academic and business organizations shape the nature of knowledge they produce. I found that strategically combining various ways of working together can lead to major learning gains ‚Äî both for the people involved and for their broader environments.
Earlier on, I completed a dual Master‚Äôs degree in ‚ÄúEconomics of Knowledge and Innovation‚Äù and ‚ÄúEconomic Policy.‚Äù Thanks to the now-defunct Erasmus Mundus program, I had the chance to study at some great universities in Turin, Paris, and Bordeaux ‚Äî and that‚Äôs where I really started focusing on knowledge as a field of study.
But even before that, I‚Äôd already honed my skills in economics during my undergraduate years at the University of Buenos Aires. There, I also had the privilege of working as an Economic Consultant on several projects with the UN‚Äôs Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (ECLAC - CEPAL), and of teaching as both an assistant and adjunct professor in various courses.
I‚Äôm originally from Patagonia.
And if you‚Äôd like to know more, well ‚Äî you know where to find me.








Outside of work, I stay active with climbing and running. I also tend to sign up for all kinds of random courses ‚Äî right now it‚Äôs screenwriting and stretching. One day, I‚Äôd love to publish a graphic humor book.
Beyond those more playful things, I try to share my take on the world and what‚Äôs going on in it through my personal blog.

  local_comp[[i]] <- decompose(local_g[[i]])
  V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg <- degree(local_comp[[i]][[1]])
  E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$width <- 12*E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$weight/max(E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$weight)
  l = layout_with_fr(local_comp[[i]][[1]])
  plot(local_comp[[i]][[1]], 
       vertex.size = 1+V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg/max(V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg)*10, vertex.label = "", 
       edge.width = E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$width,
       layout = l, 
       main = paste0("Bariloche's academic organization","\n", "ego network (largest component)" ,"\n",names(Mslice)[i])
       )
}
},interval = .8, movie.name = "bch_institutional_animation.gif")











































































































Qualitative analysis: thematic interview analysis, inductive and deductive coding, case studies



Interviews and Case Study



My experience includes conducting and analyzing interviews using Atlas.ti. I‚Äôve employed thematic analysis, including both deductive and inductive coding, to derive insights from qualitative data, enriching my research with nuanced perspectives and contextual understanding.



















Mixed methods: skilled at combining the strengths of both quantitative and qualitative approaches to gain a deeper, more integrated understanding of complex phenomena



Interviews and Case Study



In my doctoral thesis, I adopted an explanatory sequential case study design, seamlessly blending quantitative and qualitative approaches to gain comprehensive insights into complex phenomena. This methodology allowed me to uncover multifaceted patterns and inform practical recommendations.

üìå Notable Projects


PhD Thesis Exploring Knowledge Dynamics in Academia-Industry Collaborations within a Local Ecosystem


I examined knowledge production within academia-industry collaborations (AICs) in San Carlos de Bariloche, Argentina, using Boisot‚Äôs I-Space framework to characterize knowledge co-creation, and individual and organizational learning dynamics. Employing a mixed-methods approach, I integrated survey data with insights gathered from in-depth interviews to explore diverse modes of collaboration and their associated knowledge properties and learning processes. The findings provided strategic recommendations for stakeholders to enhance reciprocal learning and knowledge co-creation within AICs. Furthermore, by laying the groundwork for cross-institutional knowledge partnerships, this project contributes to shaping future strategies and policies in inter-institutional collaborations.




Network Analysis of Academic Collaborations 


During my thesis project, I extensively explored social network analysis to measure information flows within academic collaborations. While initially intending to evaluate flows in academic-industry collaborations, I found that social network analysis was not the most suitable tool for this purpose. However, this experience allowed me to develop valuable skills in analyzing collaborations between academic organizations. Leveraging bibliometric databases, I conducted original analyses to visualize and analyze evolving networks of scholarly collaboration. This culminated in a presentation at the Networks 2021: Joint Sunbelt & NetSci Conference, where I shared insights about ‚ÄúScientific Collaboration Through Institutional Networks: The Value of National Partners.‚Äù Through this project, I gained a deeper understanding of academic collaboration dynamics and enhanced my proficiency in social network analysis techniques.




Development of Economic Indicators 


My involvement in the development of economic indicators with CEPAL encompassed two primary projects. On the one hand, I contributed to the initial stages of designing and implementing a Consumer Price Index (CPI). This involved analyzing data to identify a representative consumption basket and calculating weights to ensure accurate inflation monitoring. On the other hand, I played a key role in estimating and updating coincident indicators to track the economic activity of Argentine sub-national states. This project entailed collecting new data on observable variables, deseasonalizing time series, running statistical models, and assessing data quality to inform strategic decision-making.

title: Professional and Academic Focus
text:
Professional and Academic Focus

I‚Äôve delved into diverse knowledge areas throughout my professional career, shaping my perspective. Below, I outline key areas that have captured my attention, with references to my own contributions where relevant.



Academia-Industry Collaboration (AIC)


‚ö°Ô∏è Building bridges to increase the impact of ideas üéìü§ù üíº


 The transfer of knowledge between academic and business organizations to promote innovation is the main subject I have been working on for the last 5 or 6 years. So far it has been a process which involved navigating multiple perspectives, continuously increasing in its complexity.
My PhD Thesis, titled ‚ÄúUnderstanding Knowledge Dynamics Across Modes of Academia-Industry Collaboration: A Comprehensive Mixed-Method Analysis within the I-Space Framework: Lessons from San Carlos de Bariloche, Argentina‚Äù, represent the last and most profound stage of this process.




Knowledge Management and Organizational Learning


üèò Designing strategies for the collective production of knowledge üì¶


 A critical topic I studied for my doctorate and which I now implement in my day to day.

It is worth mentioning the theoretical framework developed by Boisot (1995) for understanding information and knowledge flows in social settings: the Information Space or I-Space. In my blog, I am now trying to synthesize and use this framework to analyze the conjuncture.





Economics, Institutions, and Culture


üíº Exploring the socio-cultural foundations of economic and human behavior üìñ


 How culture and institutional arrangements define the management of resources, information, and knowledge?

Besides exploring Academia-Industry Collaborations, with another classmate of the master we made an analysis of hackerspace and makerspaces based on Ostrom‚Äôs (1990) idea of commons.
Beyond my limited contribution to the subject, a few approaches worth mentioning are innovation systems (Cooke 2001; Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff 2000; Lundvall 1988; Nelson and Rosenberg 1993), open innovation (Chesbrough 2003; Von Hippel 2005), commons (Allen and Potts 2016; Hess and Ostrom 2007; Kostakis, Niaros, and Giotitsas 2015; Ostrom 1990), and information economics (Boisot 1998).





Platforms and Digitalization


üóÇ Navigating the Digital Age üìä


 The continuous proliferation of information and communication technologies (ICTs) has a strong impact on the production of knowledge and information.

With my PhD supervisor we‚Äôve broadly explored the foundations of digital platforms and their classification.
I‚Äôm particularly drawn to theoretical perspectives like Gawer (2020). I believe understanding how these platforms are reshaping economic and social interactions is fundamental.





Graph Theory and Network Analysis


üåê Unraveling relationships beyond the actors üîó


 Representing complexity as interconnected and interdependent systems, considering both nodes and the links that connect them (B√∂rner, Sanyal, and Vespignani 2007; M. S. Granovetter 1973; M. Granovetter 1983; Newman 2018).

I have worked with bibliometric databases and survey data to analyze collaboration processes among researchers and between academic and business stakeholders. Here you can see my presentation ‚ÄúScientific Collaboration through Institutional Networks: The Value of National Partners‚Äù at the NetSci 2021 conference.





Philosophy: Pragmatism, Enactivism, Education, Psychology


üß† Philosophy in action üìú


 I have explored pragmatism and enactivists approaches (e.g., Dewey 1923; Varela, Thompson, and Rosch 2017), as well as their application in fields like education and psychology (e.g., Bereiter and Scardamalia 2014; Kress 2009; Scardamalia and Bereiter 2010).

As part of my undergraduate thesis and as a research fellow at CIECE, I researched how economic models typically fail to successfully represent complexity.






Complexity Theory and Information Theory


üß© Exploring the complexity of phenomena üìö


 Enthusiasm for emergent properties, entropy (Ben-Naim 2008), the groundbreaking work of Claude Shannon (1949), and subsequent studies in various knowledge areas (e.g., Boisot and Canals 2004; Gleick 2011; Snowden 2002; Polyanskiy and Wu 2022). I recently participated in an interesting course on complex networks.




Zettelkasten


üóÇ Creative organization ü§Ø


 The Zettelkasten technique as a source of idea generation and thought organization (Ahrens 2022).




Languages


üó£ Connecting through language üåé


 My passion for understanding cultural differences and communication patterns has inevitably led me to learn languages. In addition to my fluency in Spanish, English, Italian, and active study of Catalan, I can communicate in French. I would love to continue learning other languages.
